newsitem.title: USA: Netscape jumps on pact with Baby Bells.
newsitem.headline: Netscape jumps on pact with Baby Bells.

text.p: Shares of Netscape Communications Corp jumped after it signed a pact for five regional baby bells to use its Internet browser with their Internet access services, a move that analysts said confirmed it is still a big presence in the consumer Internet market.

"A few months ago, they announced a focus on the corporate marketplace," said Abhishek Gami, an analyst at Nesbitt Burns Securities. "This is a little reminder from them that they are still a big player in the consumer marketplace."
Netscape said the five regional Bells represent a 26-state potential market of 72 million consumers and businesses.
Netscape jumped 4-1/4, or seven percent, to 64-1/4.

Netscape said the five Baby Bells -- Ameritech Corp, Bell Atlantic Corp, BellSouth Corp, Pacific Telesis Group's and SBC Communications Inc's Southwestern Bell -- will use its new Netscape ISP Select software, which lets Internet users easily select the Internet access services of these firms, through Netscape's Web site.

In recent months, Netscape has lost some major browser wins to Microsoft Corp. A few days after Netscape signed a deal with America Online Inc, Microsoft Internet Explorer software became the preferred Internet browser on AOL.
